Top 10 Political Blunders of 2012

30/12/2012

Napoleon Bonaparte once said,"In politics, stupidity is not a handicap." Shaun Richardson looks at the biggest political blunders of 2012.

Image by

By James Bithell

With great power comes great responsibility ... and even greater mishaps. Politicians have a hard life, with little more than PS60,000 a year to cover the ever daunting task of exerting their common sense. It is entirely understandable if they make a few errors on the job. 2012 has been no exception to the rule, with more than the occasional hiccup along the way. 1. March: Budget U-turns leave the Chancellor in a spin There are two things that you can always count on, which will conjure up grumbles from the British public: the weather and the budget. However, this year, announcements of 'granny tax' and 'pasty tax' left the Chancellor more unpopular than ever when he dragged the red case to the Commons for his annual execution. Bullying the pensioners is never a good move. However, George Osborne failed to take this on board when he sailed the treasury into stormy waters by lowering the tax free allowance for those who will hit sixty-five after April 2013. The ship kept sinking when he announced a 20% rise in VAT on hot snacks but, in guidelines with the coalition's policy of absurdity, to "get them while they're cold" would avoid the tax. The coalition, already keeled over, fell full on its sword when the Prime Minister reminisced about eating a pasty - from a shop that had closed twenty years earlier! Out of touch and red faced, the government attempted a U-turn, abandoning plans for 'pasty tax', 'caravan tax' and 'charity tax'. Despite attempts to cool down the heat from hot food VAT, Osborne's blunders actually put a new word into the dictionary, "omnishambles", whilst backbenchers initiated whispers calling for Foreign Secretary, William Hague, to replace Osborne in Number 11. 2. April: Home Secretary is caught on the hook Extradition laws can be very tricky business, and Theresa May found out the hard way in her war against Abu Qatada. Eager to get the Muslim preacher out of Britain and into Jordan for good, she believed that he should not be able to appeal to the European Court of Human Rights, announcing that he could no longer block extradition attempts by the British government after his appeal deadline had been reached. However, Qatada's lawyers actually had 24 more hours left to appeal to the Court, due to confusion by the Home Secretary about when the original three month deadline limit had been set. Whilst Qatada continued to fight deportation, the Home Secretary enjoyed a celebrity party, unaware of what was going on, which led to criticism by Yvette Cooper, May's counterpart in the Shadow Cabinet. This added to previous doubt over the Home Office's competence in the dark trenches of extradition law, leaving May facing the fire of the home affairs committee. 3. June: I'm sure I've forgotten something! After a pub lunch, you arrive home and you can't help but feel that there is something missing. This was the scenario that the Prime Minister was put in after polishing off his Sunday grub, but it was not his keys, phone or wallet that he had misplaced - it was his own daughter, Nancy! Fifteen minutes later, there was a swift recovery and Nancy was in the safety of her own home, unscathed by the incident. The same could not be said for David Cameron's reputation. Ironically, this story infiltrated the headlines on the same day that the coalition's Troubled Families programme was resurrected, leaving Cameron even more red faced - maybe he needs some of that assistance? A government spokesman defended the Prime Minister as being "a busy man". This may well be true, as it is for the majority of citizens who juggle full-time jobs, child care, mortgage repayments and a dog. But is it really an excuse for forgetting about a small human being? Cameron calls for a "Big Society" but if it gets any bigger, he won't be able to find a thing! 4. August: Boris Johnson's comical public image reaches new heights An angelic pale figure glided across the London skyline. From the heavens he heralded the coming of a huge event. Gasping crowds followed the star. Yet, this was not the angel Gabriel announcing the second coming of baby Jesus. It was none other than Boris Johnson, left dangling 20 metres above the ground after a spectacular entrance descended into the pits of humiliation. The Mayor of London was meant to be promoting BT London Live as part of the Olympics 2012 activities and celebrating Britain's first gold medal. However, he instead ended up flailing around above Victoria Park for five minutes, waving Union Jacks and shouting "get me a ladder". Boris, as always, took it on the chin, but did not exactly achieve that patriotic, 'ambassador for Britain' image that he was hoping for - "he is crazy", the Rio de Janeiro mayor declared. Could we really ever trust this man to run the country? 5. September: Clegg becomes an internet icon If you are able to apologise for your mistakes you will get far in life. This was arguably true for the Deputy Prime Minister, when a very public "sorry" flew him across cyber space in only one night. After releasing a video apology, following the Liberal Democrats' failure to prevent increased university tuition fees, Alex Ross produced a remixed musical version of the speech, which received thousands of YouTube views. Clegg intended to reinvigorate support from the student electorate, but ended up being nationally ridiculed. The video, whilst not intending to have political meaning, contributed to criticism that Clegg was apologising only for promising not to raise tuition fees. He was not saying sorry for the coalition choosing to increase tuition fees. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KUDjRZ30SNo 6. September: On your bike! We common folk could not possibly understand political matters, which is why the Andrew Mitchell saga seems so ludicrous. The Chief Whip was asked by the Downing Street bobby to use the pedestrian gate whilst on his bike like everyone else but, for a public schoolboy such as Mitchell, it seems that there must be an exception. This resulted in Mitchell allegedly calling the police officer a "pleb", along with some less benign vocabulary, and the whip ended up receiving the whipping. Not long after a Cabinet reshuffle, the Prime Minister was left further shuffling his feet, faced with the difficult decision to dress the wounds inflicted by the cane of the media, slap the naughty school boy on the wrist, or give Mitchell permanent exclusion. Mitchell, however, solved it for him by crying off from his newly appointed role with his tail between his legs. However, Christmas came a week early for Mitchell, when "plebgate" later turned into "plodgate" following revelations that the police may have fabricated evidence against the former Chief Whip. Mitchell sold his sob story to The Telegraph and The Sunday Times, putting the Prime Minister in the firing line for failing to prevent Mitchell from ejecting himself from the Cabinet. Of course, Mitchell, in the eyes of many his colleagues, remained firmly in the Downing Street gutter and, despite attempts to claw back respect or credibility, his prospects for returning to the Cabinet remained bleak. These revelations did not change the fact that he had bombarded a bobby with expletives or that he believed a "long and frustrating day" justified such disrespect towards the police. 7. October: Knowing your place It is not only on the economy that the Chancellor is imposing spending cuts, while also hoping to provide satisfactory services. It seems that he's also being stingy with his own wallet, whilst equally expecting to get the same for his money. Labelled by The Guardian as "the great train snobbery", it seems that George Osborne, with his second-class train ticket, somehow managed to slip into a first-class carriage on a journey from Cheshire. When challenged by a ticket collector, his aide claimed that Osborne could not pay for an upgrade but must not move into the inferiority of second-class. Of course, for the Old Etonian to mingle with such plebs would be unimaginable! This incident occurred only weeks after 'Plebgate' had hounded the headlines, rubbing salt into the Conservatives' wounds left by a reputation for snobbery. The don and his mafia eventually paid for the upgrade, before a taking a rapid get away to their Whitehall den, with a rather hushed up response to the media. 8. October: Prescott needs a history lesson Michael Gove's plans to create an English Baccalaureate should not only be offered to secondary school pupils, but to politicians too. John Prescott, while campaigning to be elected as a PCC, demonstrated a clear lack of general knowledge when interviewed on the Daily Politics. When asked about the content of Ed Miliband's speech on "One Nation", Prescott barked, "Who the hell is Disraeli?" After falling into the hole, he just kept digging, claiming,"I'm not an intellectual, I've proved that over the years, haven't I?" You certainly have John, you certainly have! Prescott seems to think that being a traditional Labour lad provides justification for an ignorance of British history. The Tories might be seen as the "toffs", but with politicians like Prescott in the red camp, the perception of Labour is equally damaging. 9. November: I'm an MP, get me out of government! There are many ways to publicise yourself as an MP - photo shoots, public speeches, press interviews. Yet, Nadine Dorries took it to a whole new level when she jetted off from her constituency of Mid Bedfordshire to take part in the ITV reality television show, I'm a Celebrity... Get Me Out of Here! Apparently, eating bugs and getting covered in mud is a far better way of appealing to the British public than the undignified role of speaking in the House of Commons. Maybe Dorries was attempting to look like a Princess Diana figure, contending with the harsh conditions of an Australian camp, battling against the boredom inflicted by mindless celebrity conversation. She may truly believe that this is how the British function, sleeping in squalor and living off rice. Dorries had little success, being the first 'celebrity' voted from the jungle, but in her wake she left the press speculating about the wedge of cash she was fed by ITV and whether she could return to the captivity of the Westminster Zoo. Embarrassment for the coalition left her political career in doubt and even in December, she has not regained the Tory whip. She defended herself, declaring that she has never had a holiday and that the disgraced Chief Whip, Andrew Mitchell, allowed her time off, but who can blame her for that? I'd choose the coalition of Ant and Dec over Cameron and Clegg any day. 10. November: Backbenchers rebel against EU demands Brussels scrounge nearly PS9 billion from British coffers each year. It is safe to assume that the British public are not happy with this, but it seems that most of the government are not too happy either. The Prime Minister was forced to fight for cuts in our offerings to the great European god, when a lethal Eurosceptic combination of Tory and Labour MPs achieved a majority vote in favour of cutting the European budget, which the EU are planning to increase with inflation over the next few years. Not only was Cameron threatened with a break up in the party; it was also being gate crashed by Labour, while the EU was insistent on turning down the music. The occasional uprising from the underlings would not be too much of a concern for the Prime Minister, but backbenchers are getting louder and more resistant each year, with the EU budget crisis being the biggest to date. Some would say that there are only so many straws that the coalition camel can take before the backbenchers become backbreakers, and split the government for good.
